A Brief Intro to Bookdown Weixi Yao and Wangzhi Li 2019-10-23 Preface This is a preface.
2 Basic Bookdown 2.1 R code 2.2 Equations 2.3 Figures 2.4 Tables 2.5 Interactive plot

2 Basic Bookdown 2.1 R code This is a sample r code. Just like .rmd file, Some code ould be embeded in linernorm(10) and results is -0.1120213, 1.1729707, 0.316363, -0.7482966, 0.0160757, -0.6330718, 1.1467176, 1.1192202, -0.5867831, -1.4576851. Or you can put them in a code chunk: 1 + 1 ## [1] 2 rnorm(10) # 10 random numbers ## [1] 0.92942860 0.71972290 -0.77714495 -0.41485732 -0.01392456 ## [6] -1.70180487 0.25551937 -0.19077687 -1.07434517 -0.59769230 plot(dist ~ speed, cars) # a scatterplot Figure 2.1: A figure caption. 2.2 Equations $$\begin{equation*} \frac{d}{dx}\left( \int_{a}^{x} f(u)\,du\right)=f(x) \end{equation*} $$ \[\begin{equation*} \frac{d}{dx}\left( \int_{a}^{x} f(u)\,du\right)=f(x) \end{equation*} \] 2.3 Figures Figures and tables with captions will be placed in figure and table environments, respectively. par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1)) plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19) Figure 2.2: Here is a nice figure! 2.4 Tables knitr::kable( head(iris, 20), caption = 'Here is a nice table!', booktabs = TRUE ) Table 2.1: Here is a nice table! Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa 5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4 setosa 4.6 3.4 1.4 0.3 setosa 5.0 3.4 1.5 0.2 setosa 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.9 3.1 1.5 0.1 setosa 5.4 3.7 1.5 0.2 setosa 4.8 3.4 1.6 0.2 setosa 4.8 3.0 1.4 0.1 setosa 4.3 3.0 1.1 0.1 setosa 5.8 4.0 1.2 0.2 setosa 5.7 4.4 1.5 0.4 setosa 5.4 3.9 1.3 0.4 setosa 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.3 setosa 5.7 3.8 1.7 0.3 setosa 5.1 3.8 1.5 0.3 setosa 2.5 Interactive plot

3 Advanced Bookdown 3.1 Cross-reference Reference a figure by its code chunk label with the fig: prefix, e.g., see Figure 2.2. Similarly, you can reference tables generated from knitr::kable(), e.g., see Table 2.1. And it works even the item is not in this chapter. Refer to a chapter, you can use a single set of brackets with the name of that chapter [Basic Bookdown] to access to Basic Bookdown 3.2 Citation You can store your citation in a plain text .bib file and then simply cite what you want by @key. For example, R Core Team (2016) and NA (2019) Here comes a example of content in .bib file: @Journal{sample, title = {this is a sample reference}, author = {{NA}}, organization = {Test center}, address = {USA}, year = {2019}, url = {https://www.R-project.org/}, } References
4 Final Words You can do more with bookdown. Please refer to bookdown.
